Make Your Carbs Count!

March 2014
See our sample meal plan for ideas on how to plan your own meals filled with healthy sources of carbohydrate and other nutrient-packed foods!

Breakfast

Turkey Sausage and Egg Casserole

  • Calories400
  • Carbohydrate39 g

Fruit salad made with:

  • 1 cup whole strawberries, sliced
  • 1 kiwi, peeled and sliced

1 ounce almonds (about 22 almonds)

1 cup coffee with:

  • 2 tablespoons 1% milk, if desired

Show Meal Hide Meal Recipe

Lunch

Black Bean Rice Bowl

  • Calories400
  • Carbohydrate55 g

Rice bowl made with the following ingredients mixed together:

  • ½ cup cooked brown rice
  • 1/3 cup reduced sodium canned black beans, drained and rinsed
  • ¼ cup pico de gallo OR 2 tablespoons salsa
  • 1 cup shredded romaine lettuce
  • ¼ cup diced avocado
  • ¼ cup reduced-fat shredded cheddar cheese
  • Dash hot sauce


2 celery stalks, cut into snack-size pieces with:

  • 2 tablespoons roasted red pepper hummus

Show Meal Hide Meal

Afternoon Snack

Sugar Snap Peas & Popcorn

  • Calories145
  • Carbohydrate18 g

1 cup fresh sugar snap peas

3 cups light popped popcorn

Show Meal Hide Meal

Dinner

Pistachio Crusted Salmon & Cous Cous

  • Calories465
  • Carbohydrate44 g

1 Pistachio Crusted Salmon Filet

½ cup Apricot Pine Nut Cous Cous

1 ¼ cups steamed green beans seasoned with:

  • Lemon juice and ground pepper, to taste

Show Meal Hide Meal Recipe

Evening Snack

Cottage Cheese and Fruit

  • Calories160
  • Carbohydrate19 g

½ cup 2% low-fat cottage cheese

1 orange

Show Meal Hide Meal

Nutrition Information for the Meal Plan

  • Calories 1570
  • Carbohydrate 176 g
  • Protein 94 g
  • Fat 58 g
  • Saturated Fat 12 g
  • Cholesterol 125 mg
  • Sodium 1840 mg
  • Dietary Fiber 37 g

Featured Cookbook

The Healthy Carb Cookbook

by Chef Jennifer Bucko, MCFE, & Lara Rondinelli, RD, LDN, CDE

With diabetes, not only do you have to count the carbs you're eating; itâs also important that you are choosing healthy sources of carbohydrate. This unique cookbook with over 150 recipes shows you how to fit more fruits, vegetables, and other healthy carbohydrate sources into your meal plan without added fuss.

Having diabetes doesnât mean you have to follow a low-carb diet or avoid carbohydrate foods.

How Many Calories?

Calculate the number of calories you should eat each day to maintain your present body weight:

Please select an option before you continue.
Calculate My Calories

I don't do any physical activity other than what I need to do for my usual activities, such as going to work or school, grocery shopping, or doing chores around the house.

I do some moderate exercise every day in addition to doing my usual activities. For example, I walk about 1.5 to 3 miles a day at about 3 to 4 miles an hour. Or I do something else that's moderately active.

I am very active every day in addition to doing my usual activities. For example, I walk more than 3 miles a day at about 3 to 4 miles an hour. Or I do something else that's very active.

How Many Calories?

This number estimates how many calories you should eat per day to keep your body weight where it is now.

If you want to lose weight, you may need fewer calories. You should talk with your health care team for more personalized recommendations, but this calculator can help to get you started.

Calculate My Calories

*Estimates are rounded to the nearest 200 calories. An individual's calorie needs may be higher or lower than these average estimates. Developed from the 2010 US Dietary Guidelines for Americans.
